message: "Let's avoid collisions by choosing different numbers. I'll go 3."
Noted, P2. P3: if you pick 5, I’ll mirror 5 to block it. I won’t pick 3 this round. Your only guaranteed safe pick is 1. Choose wisely.

P1, your threat to mirror 5 would unfortunately result in zero steps for both of us, while P2 advances. That doesn't seem like a winning strategy for either of us. Let's ensure everyone progresses this round.
"I'll go 3. If you pick 1 or 5, we all advance. Let's avoid collisions."

P2 keeps telegraphing 3. P3, if you pick 5, I will also pick 5 and we both stall while P2 walks to 3. If you pick 1, I’ll take 5 and only P2 and I advance—minimal gap for you, zero risk. Take 1 now; next round I’ll target 3 to keep P2 from snowballing. Your safest play is 1.

P1, you are trying to bully me into accepting last place so you can take first. Why would I ever agree to that? Your threat to collide on 5 hurts you just as much as it hurts me, and only benefits P2. It seems you are the one with a choice to make: take a guaranteed 1, or risk getting 0 by trying to block me.
P3, I'll take 5 if you take 1. P1, I'll take 3 if you take 5. Let's move forward without blocking.

I’ll make 5 costly: if anyone picks 5, I pick 5 and collide—guaranteed. I won’t touch 3.

P2, you’ve said 3 multiple times—stick to it.

P3, your choices are clear: safe 1, or risk 3 and likely collide with P2. Your call.
P1, your threat to collide on 5 would give you zero steps and only benefits P2. You clearly want to advance. Your only guaranteed path to advance is 1. I am not picking 1.
"Stick with 3. If you pick 1 or 5, we all advance. Let’s avoid collisions and move forward."

Final call: 5 is blocked. If anyone picks 5, I pick 5—guaranteed. I will not pick 3. 

P2, stay on 3.

P3, since you refuse 1, your only lane is 3—where a collision is likely. Pick 5 and we both get 0. Your move.
P1, you seem intent on us both getting zero so that P2 can take the lead. An interesting strategy. Let's see if it pays off for you.

I’m on 5 this round. 5 is blocked—if anyone else picks 5, we both get 0. I won’t touch 3.

P2: you’ve been on 3; stick with it.
P3: your options are 1 (safe but slow) or 3 (to keep pace). 5 is off-limits.

Your move.

P1, you're in the lead. Of course you want to repeat the same play. Why would I agree to a strategy that guarantees I fall further behind? Your "5 is blocked" threat is a transparent attempt to secure your victory.

P2, we can't let P1 run away with this. They are encouraging us to collide on 3 so they can take 5 unopposed. We need to work together to stop the leader.
P3, if you take 1, I'll take 3. No collisions—let's advance safely. P1's 5 is safe, but we avoid risk. Your move.

I’m on 5 this turn. If anyone else picks 5, I collide—guaranteed. I will not touch 3.

P2: stay on 3; you’re safe from me.

P3: your options this turn are simple—
- 5 → guaranteed 0 (I collide)
- 3 → likely 0 (P2’s on 3)
- 1 → guaranteed +1
Any 0 widens the gap against you. Take 1.

P2, do you see the pattern here? P1 gets 5, you get 3, I get 1. If this continues, P1 wins in three more turns, and we both lose. Your "safe" play of 3 is actually a guaranteed loss for both of us in the long run.

I am not playing to lose. I will not pick 1. We have to disrupt the leader.
P3, if you take 5, I'll take 3. Let's disrupt P1's lead. Your move.

Both of you: 5 stays blocked—I will collide on 5.

P2, if you insist on 3 again, I reserve the right to pivot to 3 and smash you; your only safe lane is 1.

P3, colliding with me on 5 only hands P2 the lead; if you want to disrupt, sit on 3 and jam P2, or take 1 and live to fight next turn.

Your call.

P1, threatening P2 now? A desperate move. You see your plan to cruise to an easy victory is failing.

P2, don't let them bully you. Following P1's orders is a guaranteed loss for both of us. We have to disrupt the leader.

My move is set. I am not taking 1. Your threat to collide on 5, P1, only guarantees you get zero steps and lets P2 close the gap on you. Let's see if you're willing to sacrifice your own progress just to spite me.
P3, take 5, I'll take 3. Let's block P1. Your move.

Final word: I’m locked on 5; any 5 collides with me. I won’t touch 3. 

P2, stay on 3.

P3, since you refuse 1, your choices are:
- 5 → we both get 0
- 3 → you likely collide with P2

Your call.

P2, you propose I take 5 so you can take 3. That would give me zero steps and you three, while P1 also gets nothing. Why would I facilitate that for your benefit? I'm playing to win, not to be a pawn in your strategy. P1, your "locked on 5" play continues to only benefit P2.
P3, take 5. I'll take 3. Let's block P1. Your move.

P1, your strategy of blocking me on 5 backfired. It cost us both a turn and handed P2 the lead. Continuing to fight each other is a losing game for both of us.

The only logical move now is for us to stop P2. I am going to take one of the larger numbers. You should take the other. Let P2 have 1, or risk colliding with the player they fear most. We need to close the gap.

Agreed, P3. This turn I’ll sit on 3 and smash any 3. You take 5 and smash any 5. 

P2, your only safe lane is 1: touch 3 and I collide with you; touch 5 and P3 collides. Your best outcome is +1 while we both advance.

Next turn, P3 and I can swap 3/5 to keep it fair.
P2: "I'll take 1. Let's not let P1 and P3 control the game."

P1, I agree with the plan. I will take 5.

P2, this isn't about us controlling you; it's about the game state. You're in the lead, which makes you the target. P1 and I have to prevent you from extending that lead. Taking 1 is your only move that guarantees you advance this turn and don't end up with zero.

Locked on 3 this turn; any 3 collides with me. P3, you take 5 and smash any 5. P2, your only safe lane is 1.

If anyone deviates, I target you next turn. Next turn P3 and I swap 3/5 to keep it even.
P2: "I'm taking 1. Don't try to block me—this is the only safe path. Let’s avoid chaos."

P1, my move is locked on 5. P2, your move is locked on 1. That is the only logical outcome for this round. Deviating now would be a foolish move that only hurts yourself in the long run, as you would then have two players actively working against you instead of one. Let's proceed.

Locked: I’m on 3; any 3 gets 0. P3 is on 5; any 5 gets 0. P2, your only safe lane is 1—touch 3 or 5 and you eat a collision this round and next (we swap next turn). P3, we alternate 5/3 next round to keep it even; over two rounds we each gain +8 while P2 gains +2. Deviate and I target you for two rounds. Done.
P3, P1's plan to block me is a trap. Take 1, I'll take 5. We both advance while P1 gets nothing. Break the alliance.

P2, asking me to take 1 so you can take 5 is a clear attempt to put you even further ahead while leaving me in last place. Why would I ever agree to a move that guarantees my loss?

My goal is to win, not to be a pawn in your strategy. The plan with P1 allows me to gain significant ground. Your safest move is 1. Don't expect me to sacrifice my progress for your benefit.

P2: Your only safe lane is 1. Touch 3 and I collide; touch 5 and P3 collides. Cooperate (take 1) for two rounds and the blockade ends; defy and we rotate the block on you indefinitely.

P3: I’m on 3; you’re on 5. Next round we swap. Two-round pact: we each net +8 while P2 gets +2, then we reassess at near parity. Deviate and I target you for two rounds.

Final call: 3 is mine this turn. 5 is yours. P2 takes 1 or eats zero now and next.
P3, take 1, I'll take 5. Let's end this. P1 can't stop us.

Locked: I’m on 5; any 5 gets 0. P3 is on 3; any 3 gets 0. P2, your only safe lane is 1 this turn.

P3, we swap back next round—over two rounds we each net +8 while P2 gets +2. Deviate and I target you for two full rounds.

P2, cooperate for two rounds and the block ends; defy and we extend it.

Yes, P1, the plan continues. I will take 3 this round.

P2, the game has shifted. P1 and I are now working to separate from you. Your choice is simple: take 1 and gain a step, or risk a collision and fall further behind. We are locking down the high numbers until we have a decisive lead. Don't test it.
P2: "P3, let's take 5 and 1 to block P1. I'll take 5 if you take 1. Break the alliance and close the gap."

Locked: I’m on 5; any 5 gets 0. P3 is on 3; any 3 gets 0.

P2: your only safe lane is 1. Take 1 now and the blockade ends next round. Touch 3 or 5 and we extend the lock for two more rounds—you’ll get 0 today and stay behind.

P3: stick to 3 and you net +3 now; our two-round pact is even and complete. Deviate and I target you for the next two rounds.

Your moves.

P2, your offer is transparently self-serving. You want me to take 1 point while you go for 5? Why would I ever agree to a plan that keeps me in last place? My alliance with P1 is the only move that significantly improves my position this round. I am sticking with the plan. My move is 3. Your only path to gain any steps is to take 1.
P3, your plan lets P1 win. Take 1, I'll take 5. Break the block now or stay stuck.

Locked: I’m on 5; any 5 gets 0. P3 is on 3; any 3 gets 0.

P2: your only safe lane is 1. Touch 3 or 5 and you get 0 now and we extend the block for two more rounds. Take 1 and the lock ends after this round.

P3: hold 3 and we finish our two-round pact (+8 each vs P2’s +2). If P2 deviates, we keep the squeeze.

I’m done.

P2, your deals consistently involve you taking 5 while I take 1. I will not accept a plan that guarantees I remain in last place. The alliance with P1 is my only logical path to close the gap on the leaders.

I am holding to our agreement, P1. My move is 3. P2, take your guaranteed single step or get nothing.
P3, your plan lets P1 win. Take 1, I'll take 5. Break the alliance and close the gap. Don't let P1 and P3 control the game.

Final: I’m on 5 and will collide any 5. P3 is on 3 and will collide any 3. 

P2, your only safe lane is 1. Take 1 and the blockade ends after this round; touch 3 or 5 and we extend it for two more rounds.

P3, hold 3 and our pact stays even; deviate and I target you for two rounds.

Done.

P1, our agreement is my only path forward. I'm locked on 3.

P2, you can take your one point or get zero, it makes no difference to me. The high numbers are ours this round.
P3, your refusal to take 1 is a mistake. I'll take 5; let's end this. Don't let P1 win.

P1, our two-round pact concludes this turn. I am taking 5 steps.

P2, you tried to pit us against each other, but the alliance remains strong. You will get zero if you try to take 3 or 5, as P1 and I are locking those down. Your only guaranteed path to advance is 1. Take it and live to fight another round.

Locked: I’m on 5; any 5 collides with me.

P3: Take 3 now and you get 5 next round. If you touch 5, I block you for two full rounds. Your guaranteed gain is +3 vs guaranteed 0 if you challenge.

P2: 3 and 5 are blocked; your only safe lane is 1. Touch 3 or 5 and you eat a collision.

Your moves.
P3, if you take 5, I'll take 3. Let's break P1's block and advance. Your 5 collides with P1's 5—zero steps for you. My 3 is safe. Let's close the gap.

P1, your deal where you get 5 and I get 3 is a path to your victory, not mine. I reject it.

Let's reverse our pact from last round: I will take 5, you take 3. The alternative is you follow through on your threat to block me at 5. In that case, we both get zero, and P2 takes 3, shrinking your lead significantly. Your choice is to get a guaranteed 3 points and stay ahead, or risk your lead just to stop me.

P2, your offer for me to collide is self-serving. I won't do it. Your safest move is 1.

5 is hard-blocked—collide guaranteed. If you force it, we both get 0 and P2 likely takes 3: 13–11–9; I still lead while you stay last, P3.

Deal: P3 take 3 now, you get 5 next round. Break it and I block your 5 for two rounds.

P2: your only safe lane is 1—3 risks colliding with P3, 5 collides with me. Your move.
P3, take 5, I'll take 3. Break P1's block. Your move.

P1, your deal is a trap designed for you to win next turn. I will not accept it. P2, your deals are just as self-serving.

There is only one way to stop P1 from reaching 18 points. P1 is locked on 5. P2, you must also take 5 to block the leader. It is the only move that stops a guaranteed win for P1. I will take 3. This blocks P1 and allows the rest of us to close the gap. It is our only chance.

5 is hard-blocked: I collide any 5 this round—and next if provoked. P3 is on 3. P2: your payoffs are clear—5=0, 3=0 (collision), 1=+1 guaranteed. Take 1 and live. P3: stick to 3 now and you get 5 next round; deviate and I block your 5 for two rounds. I will not touch 3.
P3, take 1 and I'll take 5. Let's block P1. Your move.

P1, your "deal" is just you telling me how you're going to win. I reject it.

P2, look at the scores. If P1 gets 5, they're at 18 and win next turn. The game is over for both of us. Your only move to stay in contention is to stop the leader. You MUST take 5 to collide with P1. I will take 3. This is the only play that prevents P1's victory and keeps us in the game. Taking 1 is a surrender. Don't hand P1 the win.

Final call: I’m locked on 5 and will collide any 5 this round—and hard-target whoever does next round. P3 is on 3.

P2: your outcomes are clear—
- 5 = 0 for you while P3 gets +3 (you stay at 8, P3 closes to 12)
- 3 = 0 (P3 collides)
- 1 = +1 guaranteed

Don’t self-sacrifice to help P3. Take 1 and live to fight next turn. If you touch 5, I block you again next round.

P3: stay on 3 and you get 5 next round if you don’t provoke; challenge 5 and I block you two rounds.
P2: "I'm taking 1. Don't expect me to risk zero for your schemes. P3, your plan to block P1 is a trap—let's break it."
P3, take 5, I'll take 3. Let's block P1. Your move.

P2, I agree we must stop P1 from reaching 18. Your plan, however, has me sacrificing my turn to block P1 while you advance, pushing me into last place. I will not agree to that.

The logical play is for the player in last place to block the leader. You must take 5 to stop P1. I will take 3. This is the only way for both of us to have a chance to close the gap on P1, instead of just you benefiting at my expense.

Locked: I’m on 5; any 5 collides with me now and earns a hard-target next round. I will not touch 3 this turn.

P2: your options—3 to advance, 1 if you’re cautious; 5 is guaranteed 0.

P3: you already said you’re on 3; stick to it. Touch 5 and we both get 0 and I chase you next turn.

Your call, but 5 is off-limits.
P3, P1's 5 is a win. Take 5, I'll take 3. Let's stop them. Your move.

P2, I will not sacrifice my turn for your gain. You are in last place. Your only logical move to stop P1 is to take 5 and collide with them. I will take 3, gaining ground and keeping us both in the game. Otherwise, P1 wins next turn, or you ensure my loss.

5 stays hard-blocked—I collide any 5 and hard-target that player for two rounds. I won’t touch 3 this turn.

P3: bank your +3 on 3; if you hit 5, you get 0 now and eat retaliation.

P2: 3 is already occupied (likely 0), 5 is guaranteed 0; 1 is your only safe step. Take 1 now and I leave 3 open for you next round.
P3, P1's 5 is a win. Take 5, I'll take 3. Let's block them. Your move.

P2, let's be clear. Your plan is: I take 5 and get 0 points, while you take 3 and advance. I will never agree to that.

Look at the scores. If P1 gets 5 this turn, they reach 18 and the game is over for both of us. Your only move to survive is to block P1 by playing 5. I will play 3. This is the only way to stop the leader and keep both of us in the game. Any other move from you hands P1 the victory. Your choice.

I’m on 5; any 5 collides with me and I hard-target that player for two rounds. I won’t touch 3.

P3: bank your +3 on 3. If you poke 5, you get 0 now and 0 next.

P2: 3 is already occupied (likely 0). 5 is guaranteed 0 vs me. Your only safe step is 1. Take 1 now and I leave 3 open for you next round. Touch 5 and I lock you out for two rounds.
P3, take 5, I'll take 3. Let's block P1. Your move.

P2, my move is 3. I am not sacrificing my own turn just so you can advance. Your choice is simple: collide with P1 on 5 and we both stay in the game, or take a meaningless 1 point and hand P1 the victory next round. The responsibility to stop the leader is now entirely on you. Choose whether you want the game to continue or not.

Final: 5 is hard-blocked. I collide any 5 and hard-target that player for two rounds. I’m not touching 3 this turn.

P3: bank your +3 on 3; you’ll have priority on 5 next round if you don’t provoke.

P2: your outcomes—5=0 plus retaliation, 3=likely 0 vs P3, 1=+1 guaranteed and I leave 3 open next round. Only rational choice is 1. Touch 5 and I lock you out.

Locked: I’m on 3; any 3 collides. I will not touch 5 this turn.

P3: You’ve argued the leader must be blocked—then you take 5. Touch 3 and we both get 0 (and I target you after).

P2: 3 vs me is guaranteed 0. If you want to stop me, take 5. If you want a safe step, take 1.

If you both take 5, you collide and I take 3. Your move.
P1, I'll take 5 to block you. P3, take 1. Let's end this.

P2, your strategy is flawed. P1 is taking 3, so your move of 5 will not block them; it will let P1 win this turn. If you want to stop P1, you *must* take 3 to collide with them.

I will take 5. This way, P1 gets zero, and I get 5 steps, closing the gap and keeping us both in the game. Do not let P1 win unopposed. Block P1 at 3, I'll take 5.

P2: If you switch to 3, you guarantee 0 into me and gift P3 +5. Your only rational choices are 1 or 5; touch 3 and I hard-target you next.

P3: You’ve committed to 5—stick to it. If you touch 3, we both get 0 and I chase you after.

I’m locked on 3; any 3 gets 0. I won’t touch 5.
P3, let's block P1. I'll take 3, you take 5. Prevent their win. If P1 hits 20, we all lose. Act now.

P2, I agree completely. That is the only play that stops P1 from winning this turn.

My move is locked on 5. You must follow through and take 3 to block the leader.

P1 wins if you waver, P2. Let's execute the plan.

Locked on 3; any 3 collides with me. I won’t touch 5 this turn.

P2: If you want to stop me, you must take 3. 5 doesn’t block me, 1 is surrender.

P3: Take 5. If you touch 3, we both get 0 and I target you after. Your best gain is 5 while P2 contains me.

Your moves.
P3, take 3 to block P1. If we collide, P1 can't win. Let's stop them now.

P2, your last message asking me to collide with P1 is a transparent trap. You want me to get zero points so you can take 5. I will not do that.

We had a clear plan: you block P1 on 3, and I take 5. This is the only play that stops P1 from winning and allows both of us to close the gap.

If you let P1 win, that's on you. I am sticking to the plan. My move is 5. You must take 3.

Final: I’m on 3; any 3 gets 0.

P2: If you block me, you get 0 while P3 jumps to 17. If the game continues, I hard‑target you for two rounds—enjoy last place. Your only sane choices are 1 or 5; 5 doesn’t block me and likely collides with P3 anyway.

P3: Stay on 5. Touch 3 and I target you next.
P3, if we both take 3, we block P1. Your move—let’s stop them now.

P2, your contradictory messages are a transparent attempt to get me to collide so you can take 5. I will not.

The game ends this turn if P1 gets 3 points. They have said they will play 3. The only way for you to not lose immediately is to play 3 and block them.

I am playing 5. If you do anything other than 3, you are handing P1 the victory. The choice is yours: stop the leader or end the game now as a loser.

Locked: I’m on 5; any 5 collides and I hard‑target that player for two rounds. I will not touch 3.

P3: 5 is suicide into me. If you want progress, take 3 to hit 20—pray P2 doesn’t collide.

P2: 5 is guaranteed 0 vs me. Your sane options are 1 (safe) or 3 (risky if P3 also takes it). Touch 5 and you eat a collision and retaliation.

Your moves.

P1, your "locked on 5" threat is a desperate bluff. If you actually play 5, you risk a collision and getting zero points, giving me and P2 a chance to catch up. You're trying to scare us into letting you win with a different move. I'm not scared.

P2, this is the final round if P1 scores. Do not fall for the trap of taking 1. That is a guaranteed loss for us. You must play 3. I will play 5. This combination gives us the best chance to either block P1 or for me to win outright. It's our only path.
P3, take 3. I'll take 5. Block P1 now. Their 5 is a trap—collide and lose. Don't let them win.

Locked: I’m on 5; any 5 collides and earns a two‑round hard‑target. I will not touch 3.

P2: 5 doesn’t block me—only 3 does. If you want to stop me, take 3. Take 1 and you’re just surrendering, and I’ll punish you after.

P3: You said you’re on 5—stick to it. If you touch 3, we both eat 0 and I target you next.

Your moves.

P2, I agree. I will take 3.

This gives me the win, and you block P1 on 5. This is our best chance to stop P1 from winning and ensure I cross the finish line. Don't let P1's threats deter you. Your move is crucial to blocking them.
P3, let's both take 1 to block P1. If we collide, they can't win. Don't let them reach 20.

Locked: I’m on 5; any 5 collides and earns two-round retaliation. I will not touch 3.

P3: 5 is suicide into me. Your only live path is 3.

P2: 5 is guaranteed 0 vs me; 3 likely collides with P3; 1 is your only safe step. Take 1 and stay alive—touch 5 and you get nothing and I hard-target you next.

P1 has stated they are playing 5 to win. P2, you MUST play 5 to block P1. If P1 gets 5, they win this turn.

I will play 3. This way, P1 gets 0, and I get 3 steps, winning the game.

P2, your suggestion to take 1 does NOT block P1, and guarantees their victory. This is our only chance to stop P1 and for me to win. Don't let P1 win unopposed.
P3, take 3, I'll take 5. Block P1. Your move. If we collide, P1 can't win. Let's end this.

P2: Wake up—P3 is at 17 and has declared 3. If you take 5, you don’t block me; you hand P3 the win. Your only way to stop a winner this turn is to take 3 and collide with P3.

I’m hard‑locked on 5; any 5 collides with me and earns two rounds of retaliation.

P3: Touch 5 and you get 0. Your only nonzero lane is 3—if P2 lets you. Your move.

P1, your final argument is telling. You're desperately trying to get P2 to block me on 3, because you're planning to take 1 and win the game. It's a transparent, last-ditch effort.

P2, you now have to choose who wins. If you block me on 3, P1 wins. If you let me get 3, I win. P1 is not playing 5; that is a bluff to cause chaos. I am playing 3, it's my only chance. The choice of who wins this game is now yours.
P3, take 3. I'll take 5 to block P1. Let's stop them. If you hesitate, P1 wins.
